survivalByClassAndGender.title: Survival by Passenger Class and Gender

survivalWithSibSp.title: Survival rate with and without Sibling/Spouse aboard

notes.start: Overall survival vs non-survival across all passengers. Use this as a quick, high-level snapshot before diving into details.
notes.overviewSex: Compare survival counts between genders. Colors are categorical, not value-laden.
notes.overviewClass: Compare survival counts by passenger class (1/2/3). Higher classes generally show higher survival counts.
notes.overviewAge: Histogram of ages in 5-year bins to reveal the overall age profile and gaps.
notes.distributionSex: Gender composition of the dataset (not survival).
notes.survivalAge: Line chart of survival rate by age groups. Values shown are percentages of survivors within each age bucket.
notes.heatmap: Heatmap of Pearson correlation among numeric variables (Age, Fare, Pclass, Survived).
notes.pearson: Pearson coefficients for selected pairs. Use absolute magnitude to judge strength (±1 strong, 0 weak).
notes.spearman: Spearman rank correlation is robust to non-linear monotonic relationships and outliers.
notes.avgAgeByClass: Average age across ticket classes; illustrates demographic differences by class.
notes.byClassGender: Survivor counts broken down by class and gender; highlights prioritization and access dynamics.
notes.withSibSp: Survival rate difference for passengers traveling with vs without siblings/spouses.

welcome.title: Welcome to the Titanic Dashboard
welcome.body: Welcome to our Titanic dataset analysis. This dashboard provides an in-depth overview of the Titanic passengers, including their survival rates, demographics, and class distribution. Here, you will find various visualizations and metrics to help you understand the dataset better. Start by exploring the "Overview" section for key insights and statistics.

bullets.overview1: - Female survival rate ~{femaleRate}% is notably higher than male ~{maleRate}%.
bullets.overview2: - By passenger class, survival rates for 1st/2nd/3rd are {r1}% / {r2}% / {r3}%, reflecting access differences to lifeboats and assistance.
bullets.distribution1: - Gender distribution: compare proportions of male/female passengers in the dataset (not survival).
bullets.distribution2: - Age distribution: majority fall into young-to-middle adulthood; some records have missing ages.
bullets.survival1: - Survival rate varies by age: younger groups generally have higher survival, while older groups trend lower.
bullets.insight1: - Average age tends to decrease with lower classes, indicating distinct demographic profiles by class.
bullets.insight2: - Across classes, female survivor counts exceed male, highlighting prioritization dynamics during rescue.
bullets.insight3: - Travelling with siblings/spouse shows a different survival rate vs travelling alone, suggesting the role of social support.

explain.corText1: - Pearson measures linear relationships. Values near +1/−1 indicate strong positive/negative linear correlation; near 0 indicates weak or no linear relationship.
explain.corText2: - Spearman (rank correlation) is useful for monotonic but non-linear relationships or when outliers are present.
